question: What is the most commonly used pain scale for the measurement of pain in children?
ideal_answer: The most pain scale used to measure pain in children is FLACC (Face, leg, activity, cry, and consolability) score.

snippets.text: Face, leg, activity, cry, and consolability (FLACC) scores for postoperative pain were also assessed.
The FLACC and COMFORT scales were utilized to assess pain
Postoperative pain was assessed using the Visual Analogue Scale (VAS), the Wong-Baker Faces Pain Rating Scale, and the Face, Legs, Activity, Cry, and Consolability (FLACC) scale.
The pain experience (intense, moderate, or mild) was evaluated by the Face, Legs, Activity, Cry, Consolability-revised scale (FLACC-r).

Daily assessment and documentation for pain (81%) and sedation (87%) was reported by most of the PICUs, using the preferred validated FLACC scale (54%) and the COMFORT Behavioural scale (48%), respectively.

exact_answer: FLACC, Face, leg, activity, cry, and consolability, COMFORT Behavioural scale, Faces Pain Scale - Revised, FPS-R, FLACC-r
